results.title: The Tank Gang: A Say No to Bullies Story
results.creator_credit: Willem Durrand, Tahalia Durrand and Ruben Durrand
results.brief_description: This is the story of the Tank Gang. The Tank Gang love playing together, even with Jack, the bully. One day, Jack goes too far and the Tank Gang see how putting up with Jack has meant that their friend got hurt. The friends all learn the importance of standing up for each other, not bullying and being good friends.

results.title: Show Me the Magic: The Adventures of Don McAlpine [Q&A]
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Cathy Henkel’s 2012 documentary ‘Show Me the Magic’ about Australian cinematographer Don McAlpine brought together personal and professional connections, including Gillian Armstrong, Bruce Beresford and Baz Lurhmann, to explore his life and career.

This question and answer session with Cathy Henkel and Don McAlpine, chaired by Rochelle Siemienowicz, was held at ACMI in September 2013 following a screening of the documentary.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Natasha Pincus
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Natasha Pincus is a multi award winning Australian music video director and producer and has won the ARIA award for Best Music Video two years in a row. Her stop motion animation video for Gotye’s ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ has had a staggering 420 million views. Natasha talks about getting her first big break making a music video for Paul Kelly.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow

results.brief_description:
‘Oh Yeah Wow’ are a Melbourne based creative collective that make music videos, short films and TV programs. In this interview directors Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury and Josh Thomas discuss music videos.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Hello Flux Panel Discussion
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Spectacle Talks: Hello Flux Panel Discussion

results.brief_description:
A special panel discussion held at ACMI on 26th September 2013. Exhibition curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells joined an extended panel that included Alexei Tylevich (the designer of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’) and Australian music video directors Darcy Prendergast, Josh Thomas, Luci Schroder and Kris Moyes.
Moderated by ACMI curator Amita Kirpalani, the panel discusses the exhibition, personal experiences in production and the art of the music video. Filmed as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Spectacle: Interview with Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Spectacle: Interview with Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells

results.brief_description:
“How many exhibitions would have the range of Bob Dylan to Kanye West?” (Jonathan Wells)
Flux Curators Jonathan Wells and Meg Grey Wells share what inspired ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’, the challenges in bringing over 300 clips into an exhibition context and their favourite areas in the exhibition.
Created as part of ‘Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition’ 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014.

results.title: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
ACMI’s ‘Australian Perspectives’ film season frames contemporary Australian filmmaking against a backdrop of archival classics and special guest presentations.
This question and answer session with a panel of Australian film industry figures, was held on Saturday 7th September 2013 as Part 2 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’, following a screening of Nigel Buesst’s 1971 film ‘Bonjour Balwyn’.
Hosted by Rochelle Siemienowicz, the panel included Nigel Buesst, Peter Hourigan, Alan Finney and John Flaus.
The discussion highlights the key role of Melbourne, and Carlton in particular, as a centre for independent filmmaking in the 1960s and 1970s. The memories and anecdotes recounted by the panellists illustrate the vibrancy and creative energy of the Melbourne scene and the socio-economic context that allowed it to flourish.
NOTE: Part 1 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’ was an August 2013 screening of Brian Davies’ 1966 film ‘Pudding Thieves’.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Paul Goldman
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Acclaimed Australian filmmaker Paul Goldman has directed over 200 music videos including work for Elvis Costello, INXS, Kylie Minogue, Crowded House and Silverchair. Paul also directed seminal Australian films like ‘Australian Rules’ and ‘Suburban Mayhem’. In this inverview, Paul talks candidly about his early music videos for Nick Cave’s ‘The Birthday Party’ and ‘The Reels’.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

video_links.name: Hollywood Costume: What is Costume Design? with Prof. D. Nadoolman Landis

results.brief_description:
In a special event held at ACMI as part of the ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition, curator Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis introduced the art of costume design and discussed its role in cinematic storytelling.
Landis, an Oscar®-nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘The Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is also the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning exhibition catalogue, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes.
Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.
